history.content:
The base things of proof writing you'll need for Math110 can be found in note2, note3, and note4. Specifically, note 2 was often used in my semester of 110, because the professor liked to prove things using a contrapositive technique, and it's important to understand why that works. 

That being said, the only prerequisites for 110 is 54, not 70 nor 55, so you can take the two courses together. Math110 is designed to be the first upper division math course you take, so it's more gentle with introducing proofs and building proof skills than 104 or 113. 

If you take 110 and 70 together, I would recommend:

- skimming those three notes during the summer before classes start

- balancing your schedule with very different classes to offset two heavy pset courses -   that's a lot of math you'll be doing. 

110 reviews some basics from 54 in the first few weeks so you should be good there.

<md>Hi, I'm wondering if it'd be advisable to take Math 110 alongside 70. I'm not too familiar with proofs/theory, so I was wondering if it'd be better to save Math 110 for after 70. For reference, I've taken EE16A&B but not Math 54. If it would be advisable to take Math 110 alongside 70, what are some important things to review beforehand (either from Math 54 or 70)? Thank you!</md>
history.subject: Math 110
